title: For Sale:  CCW Holsters, Inside The Waistband
location: North of Columbus (free shipping), Columbus, Ohio
postcontent:
If you have, or are thinking of getting your CCW license then you'll need a good holster. A quality holster is paramount when taking on the responsibility of carrying a firearm.


 Hero Holsters LLC offers high-quality inside the waistband (IWB) holsters at a very competitive price. We are also the first to offer in our regular lineup, an IWB with true level one retention by way of a thumb break. Some people say that active retention on a concealed holster is pointless. Sure, if gun safety and peace of mind is pointless then yes it is.

If you're new to the idea of IWB carry, let's go over the benefits:
1) Highly concealable. An outside holster has much more likelihood to "print" against the clothing covering it. IWBs all but disappear.
 2) Ease of reholstering. A cheap nylon "fits-all" type of holster will collapse inside the waistband as soon as you draw the gun. This makes range time very frustrating.
3) Comfort. Yes, really- the leather across the back goes towards the body and spreads the contact of the weapon out across the body to avoid points of pressure.

Come take a look at our website at www.HeroHolsters.com. Hero Holsters LLC was founded by a Sheriff's detective with ten years on the job before getting shot multiple times and having to taking a medical retirement.

A hero is an ordinary person who does an extraordinary thing. Be extraordinary.

Open top holsters are $50. The Officer model with active retention is $65.

The FLT Mount is lightweight weighing in at only 5.5 ounces, and is 5 inches long. It is low profile allowing excellent cheek weld when mounted to the AR-15/M16 flattop upper receiver. The height from the centerline of the 30mm integral rings to the top of the dovetail mounting platform is 1.460 inches. The center to center dimension of the rings is 3.750 inches. The FLT Accucam Quick Detach Scope Mount provides you with a solid method to quickly install or remove the scope from the weapon. The scope can quickly be installed on a dovetail rail in seconds by rotating the Accucam Lever to the locked position and can just as quickly be removed by rotating the Accucam Cam Lever to the unlocked position. It is fully adjustable to fit Weaver and MIL-STD-1913 dovetails. The Accucam mechanism is manufactured from solid billet 4140 steel. It can be purchased for an additional $160.00 (Scope mount not included). THE PROCESS: Purchasing a firearm online is easy. You only need to send us two things: 1: payment for the item and 2: a copy of a Federal Firearms License (FFL) from a licensed dealer in your state. Money Order , cash, or bank check only (NO PERSONAL CHECKS). I will ship your purchase within five days of receiving your dealer's FFL and payment has cleared. This means cleared in my account. It is your responsibility to know if this legal to own in your state. I do not know every state law so don't ask me. Please allow 24 to 48 hours to process shipping. Your dealer may charge you for the Firearm Transfer, which is completely between you and your dealer. title: For Sale:  Magpul MBUS Gen 2 PTS Black
postcontent:
For Sale is a set of Magpul MBUS PTS in Black.  We have many sets available if you are interested.  Because of our last listing I thought I would clear up a few misconceptions. 
PTS does not mean airsoft, it stands for Practice, training, simulation.  These sights were made under license from Magpul.  They are from the same Dupont polymer as the top end line many call the MOE MBUS.  Since we sell both of the sets we have been able to compare similarities and longevity.  To me these are not much different than the MOE line, size, function, spring, brand of screws, etc.  These make extremely cost effective back up sights,  after all these are like I said "back up sights"  opened up only when your optics loose battery life.  Magpul is not going to water down their brand even in this lower end market by putting out a subpar product.  I do warn there are copies/clones all over the place, but we had a supplier out of Denver com to us with these a few years ago and proved to us these were a licensed product, even gave us 4 months to sample and demo sets to see if we approved.  

Happy Shooting everyone,

Alan
The WerkShop

title: For Sale:  Russia has NOT stopped exporting ammo, don't feed the gougers
postcontent:
Representatives from both Wolf and Tulammo have made statements today that Russian ammo is still flowing as usual into the United States. Wolf also stated that Russia is NOT the only source for x39 and x54 ammunition, which is a fact, and that they have sources lined up for any eventuality that might disrupt the flow from factories due to the current Russia/Crimea condition. PLEASE do research on this and you will fine that it all started with ONE post from James Yeager, just do a search on him and you'll see why he is NOT a credible source for any information...

These sorts of posts are what caused and fed the last two panic-buying and extreme gouging on ammunition. If you repost ignorant and flat out WRONG things like this, all you do is create the problem and you are a PART of the problem as well. Classic Arms just announced a BIG sale on Wolf of all calibers, Royal Tiger has a great deal on tins of Romanian x39, AIM surplus just posted a big sale on steel cased ammo...you think they'd do this if supply was cut off? Use your brains people...

title: For Sale:  Speer 223 Nickel Plated Brass - Awsome Stuff!
postcontent:
I have right around 1,500 pieces out of the 4,000 pieces of Speer 223 Nickel Plated Brass left from 4 days ago when I ran the add.
 This is all once fired, very clean, and should re-load 7-8 times. 
 This brass will feed smoother than regular brass and besides the ease of chambering in your gun it holds sub-MOA at over 125 yrds in a ruger m77 mkII varmint. 
 There are some great benefits to Nickel Plated Brass that many don't realize and it is the reason all your high dollar ammo makers use it in rounds that really count:
 1. Reduced Friction: Nickel is harder than the brass from which cartridge cases are made. The nickel plating on the outside of the case prevents dirt and grit from embedding in the surface of the case. This reduces the friction of the case as it works its way through the magazine, into the chamber prior to firing and then out of the chamber after the shooter fires the cartridge.
 2. Corrosion Resistance: Brass is susceptible to corrosion, especially if it is exposed to the elements. Leather cartridge belts, in particular, tend to cause brass to corrode. This corrosion may eventually damage the cartridge, and it can also interfere with the operation of the rifle or pistol. Nickel plating almost completely eliminates this type of corrosion. 
 3. Increased Visibility: The case is the most expensive component of a cartridge. It is also the only reusable component. Shooting hobbyists who reload their spent cases must search the ground to retrieve any cases they may have dropped. This is a good idea even for those who do not reload. The problem is that unplated brass cases develop a patina upon firing, which makes them blend into the ground. A nickel plated case remains shiny even after firing, so it is much easier to spot.
 4. Damage Visibility: Scratches in a cartridge case can render it unsuitable for reloading. Also, once a case has been reloaded multiple times, it begins to wear out and develop thin areas. The patina that a brass case develops after firing can mask these danger signals. The nickel on a plated case is thin and relatively easy to damage, and the underlying brass tends to show through any scratches or other damage. This serves as an indication to the hobbyist to discard the case, rather than reloading it.

 I'm asking 9.90 per hundred on it and if it was un-fired rather than once-fired, it would be worth 28.00+ for a 100 and then after you loaded and shot it once you would be right here, but at 3 times the money.

 I only have this one 4000 lot batch and then its gone, so if your wanting some please don't wait long, or you will miss out.

 It will be shipped only and the price is thus:
 200 pieces Shipped to you 25.00. That is a small 2 day Priority Box.
 400 Pieces will be 2 boxes at 25.00
 Over 400 pieces will be in a Medium Box, or Large if Someone wants a big batch.

 Pay Pal is my preference and give you the buyer 100% safety if there is any problem.
 I also take credit cards over the phone and can do a check in the mail if needed.

 I ship every day Monday - Friday. When payment is received I buy postage and e-mail you with information and tracking number. I pack and ship brass the following day. From payment to receiving brass usually takes 3 days total, excluding weekends, and its delivered to your front door.

 When enquiring please let me know how many pieces your looking to get and I will shoot you a price with shipping included and then you can go from there.

 I also have large quantities of 223 in regular brass also and 9mm, 40s&w, 45acp, 38Sp, etc. and limited quantities of other rifle brass. If you send me an e-mail I will let you know availability and prices.

 Thanks,
 Mitch
 REDACTED

 This brass will feed smoother than regular brass and besides the ease of chambering in your gun it holds sub-MOA at over 125 yrds in a ruger m77 mkII varmint. 
 There are some great benefits to Nickel Plated Brass that many don't realize and it is the reason all your high dollar ammo makers use it in rounds that really count:
 1. Reduced Friction: Nickel is harder than the brass from which cartridge cases are made. The nickel plating on the outside of the case prevents dirt and grit from embedding in the surface of the case. This reduces the friction of the case as it works its way through the magazine, into the chamber prior to firing and then out of the chamber after the shooter fires the cartridge.
 2. Corrosion Resistance: Brass is susceptible to corrosion, especially if it is exposed to the elements. Leather cartridge belts, in particular, tend to cause brass to corrode. This corrosion may eventually damage the cartridge, and it can also interfere with the operation of the rifle or pistol. Nickel plating almost completely eliminates this type of corrosion. 
 3. Increased Visibility: The case is the most expensive component of a cartridge. It is also the only reusable component. Shooting hobbyists who reload their spent cases must search the ground to retrieve any cases they may have dropped. This is a good idea even for those who do not reload. The problem is that unplated brass cases develop a patina upon firing, which makes them blend into the ground. A nickel plated case remains shiny even after firing, so it is much easier to spot.
 4. Damage Visibility: Scratches in a cartridge case can render it unsuitable for reloading. Also, once a case has been reloaded multiple times, it begins to wear out and develop thin areas. The patina that a brass case develops after firing can mask these danger signals. The nickel on a plated case is thin and relatively easy to damage, and the underlying brass tends to show through any scratches or other damage. This serves as an indication to the hobbyist to discard the case, rather than reloading it.

 I'm asking 9.90 per hundred on it and if it was un-fired rather than once-fired, it would be worth 28.00+ for a 100 and then after you loaded and shot it once you would be right here, but at 3 times the money.

 I only have this one 4000 lot batch and then its gone, so if your wanting some please don't wait long, or you will miss out.

 It will be shipped only and the price is thus:
 200 pieces Shipped to you 25.00. That is a small 2 day Priority Box.
 400 Pieces will be 2 boxes at 25.00
 Over 400 pieces will be in a Medium Box, or Large if Someone wants a big batch.

 Pay Pal is my preference and give you the buyer 100% safety if there is any problem.
 I also take credit cards over the phone and can do a check in the mail if needed.

 I ship every day Monday - Friday. When payment is received I buy postage and e-mail you with information and tracking number. I pack and ship brass the following day. From payment to receiving brass usually takes 3 days total, excluding weekends, and its delivered to your front door.

 When enquiring please let me know how many pieces your looking to get and I will shoot you a price with shipping included and then you can go from there.

 I also have large quantities of 223 in regular brass also and 9mm, 40s&w, 45acp, 38Sp, etc. and limited quantities of other rifle brass. If you send me an e-mail I will let you know availability and prices.

title: For Sale:  Used CZ 75 SHADOW SA/DA 9mm BLACK CUSTOM SHOP
postcontent:
This is a used gun in good condition. 

Custom Version of Shadow
 Shadow Competition Rear Sight CZ
 Fiber Optic Front Sight
 CZ Custom SA DA Hammer & Main Spring
 Stainless Steel Guide Rod
 Tune Trigger Components (Reduces Single and Double action trigger pull)
 Install and Tune 13lb Main Spring and 11lb Recoil Spring
 Re profile and Polish Disconnector and associated surfaces.
 Re Profile Slide Stop For Magazine release with Heavy / Long Bullets
 Polish underside of Disconnector rail and break breach face edge
Thin Black Aluminum Grips 
Includes (3) 18 round 9mm magazines We will swap for 10 round magazines for appropriate states
Reliability Check. Zero Check with Factory Ammunition 

FAQ on trigger Pull 

The CZ custom hammer will give you a "full" trigger pull of about 3.8 to 4.2lbs but creep free.  The reason I say ?full? is that is what the trigger will need to activate fully. I.e. hanging a weight on the trigger. If we could actually weight the break point of the sear less the trigger return spring, The actual beak point of the sear hammer engagement is about 1.5/2.0Lbs the rest is the trigger return spring, since we normally don't let the trigger all the way forward for subsequent shot the sear break point matter more then overall trigger weight. To lighten the trigger more it is necessary to lighten the trigger return spring, this can be done by careful bending, also replace the mainspring with something lighter a 13lb or 15lb mainspring, this depends on the type of ammo you are going to shoot? I shoot a 13Lb mainspring, having said that I load my own ammo so can choose the primer sensitivity and depth.   
Any Questions you can call me anytime and Ill get back to you ASAP  (seven-one-five)two-one-nine-one-one-four-two.  My name is Kyle,  Thanks

I have right around 1,500 pieces out of the 4,000 pieces of Speer 223 Nickel Plated Brass left from 4 days ago when I ran the add.
 This is all once fired, very clean, and should re-load 7-8 times. 
 This brass will feed smoother than regular brass and besides the ease of chambering in your gun it holds sub-MOA at over 125 yrds in a ruger m77 mkII varmint. 
 There are some great benefits to Nickel Plated Brass that many don't realize and it is the reason all your high dollar ammo makers use it in rounds that really count:
 1. Reduced Friction: Nickel is harder than the brass from which cartridge cases are made. The nickel plating on the outside of the case prevents dirt and grit from embedding in the surface of the case. This reduces the friction of the case as it works its way through the magazine, into the chamber prior to firing and then out of the chamber after the shooter fires the cartridge.
 2. Corrosion Resistance: Brass is susceptible to corrosion, especially if it is exposed to the elements. Leather cartridge belts, in particular, tend to cause brass to corrode. This corrosion may eventually damage the cartridge, and it can also interfere with the operation of the rifle or pistol. Nickel plating almost completely eliminates this type of corrosion. 
 3. Increased Visibility: The case is the most expensive component of a cartridge. It is also the only reusable component. Shooting hobbyists who reload their spent cases must search the ground to retrieve any cases they may have dropped. This is a good idea even for those who do not reload. The problem is that unplated brass cases develop a patina upon firing, which makes them blend into the ground. A nickel plated case remains shiny even after firing, so it is much easier to spot.
 4. Damage Visibility: Scratches in a cartridge case can render it unsuitable for reloading. Also, once a case has been reloaded multiple times, it begins to wear out and develop thin areas. The patina that a brass case develops after firing can mask these danger signals. The nickel on a plated case is thin and relatively easy to damage, and the underlying brass tends to show through any scratches or other damage. This serves as an indication to the hobbyist to discard the case, rather than reloading it.

 I'm asking 9.90 per hundred on it and if it was un-fired rather than once-fired, it would be worth 28.00+ for a 100 and then after you loaded and shot it once you would be right here, but at 3 times the money.

 I only have this one 4000 lot batch and then its gone, so if your wanting some please don't wait long, or you will miss out.

 It will be shipped only and the price is thus:
 200 pieces Shipped to you 25.00. That is a small 2 day Priority Box.
 400 Pieces will be 2 boxes at 25.00
 Over 400 pieces will be in a Medium Box, or Large if Someone wants a big batch.

 Pay Pal is my preference and give you the buyer 100% safety if there is any problem.
 I also take credit cards over the phone and can do a check in the mail if needed.

 I ship every day Monday - Friday. When payment is received I buy postage and e-mail you with information and tracking number. I pack and ship brass the following day. From payment to receiving brass usually takes 3 days total, excluding weekends, and its delivered to your front door.

 When enquiring please let me know how many pieces your looking to get and I will shoot you a price with shipping included and then you can go from there.

 I also have large quantities of 223 in regular brass also and 9mm, 40s&w, 45acp, 38Sp, etc. and limited quantities of other rifle brass. If you send me an e-mail I will let you know availability and prices.

 Thanks,
 Mitch
 REDACTED

title: For Sale/Trade:  Remington 700, Left-Handed, in 338 Win Mag
location: Bergen County, New Jersey, United States
postcontent:
I have a Remington 700 that I picked up at an estate sale.  I don't have much info on it because the heirs to the estate weren't familiar with it.  I grabbed it because I was intrigued by "left-handed."  Apparently, it is not what I was hoping for.  I gave it to a gunsmith buddy of mine for a once-over and this is what he said...
It is a left handed, long action, model 700.  It appears to be glass bedded in an olive drab, aftermarket (possibly McMillan) stock.  It has a stainless, aftermarket, 22"ish (if memory serves correct) barrel, with a threaded muzzle with a cap.  He said the action and trigger appear to have been "worked."  It looks like an ADL (no trap door), but without removing it from the stock, he couldn't be certain.
This rifle has seen some use, and I won't pretend to believe that it was a safe queen, but it is a really nice rifle, with a REALLY smooth action.  The round count is unknown.

More pics available, but Armslist has a limit of 4mb for images.

Up for sale is this Original Baby Desert Eagle 9mm Pistol manufactured by Israel Military Industries, now know as Israel Weapons Industries, imported by Magnum Research. This pistol is in EXCELLENT CONDITION AND COMES WITH BOX AND PAPERWORK. 
This is one of the original ones imported some 20+ years ago. On the left hand side of the frame it is marked Israeli Military Industries and Desert Eagle Pistol. It is also marked made in Israel. THERE ARE NO "Baby Eagle" MARKINGS ON THE GUN. THIS IS THE IMI PISTOL, NOT THE NEWER IWI.

title: For Sale/Trade:  AR-15 Upper Complete 223 NIB
postcontent:
AR-15 Upper Complete These are really nice, Function Tested, and ready to drop in to any lower and start firing... 

Upper is machined from 7075-T6 forgings that are hard coat anodized for wear and scratch resistance meeting MIL SPEC

Barrels drilled, reamed and buttoned from 4140, 4150 Chrome Moly, Chrome Moly Vanadium per MIL –B-11595E or 
416 stainless gun quality steel then stress relieved prior to contouring and chambering. 

Twist rate is 1 in 9. The barrels are chambered in the highly desireable .223 Wylde and therefore chambered for and suitable for firing either the Nato 5.56 designation or the .223 Remington commercial round. 


The head space is set and the barrel is tested for straightness using a 6” drop pin gage. 

The steel barrel assemblies are Parkerized to eliminate rusting. Bolts machined from tool steel, hardened and tempered 
to provide maximum wear characteristics then Parkerized to eliminate rusting. 

Bolt carriers machined from 8620 gun quality steel, heat treated and tempered to maximize strength and wear characteristics then Parkerized to eliminate rusting. These work great with our complete lowers...

The barrels on these are made from 4140 cold rolled steel and are rated at a barrel life of approximately 150,000 rounds. They are very top end. 

They are not chrome lined as most AR-'s are not. Chrome lining on modern rifles is typically used where there is a high probability of corrosive ammo being used such as AK type rifles chambered for foreign calibers... 

Since chrome lining may slightly affect accuracy, and since most AR-15 rifles are designed with accuracy as a benchmark, 
and since virtually all .223 / 5.56 Nato is non corrosive...most AR manufacturers do not chrome line barrels. 


* No FFL required on the uppers as they are not the serial numbered part and not considered a firearm.
These can and should ship directly to the end user.

title: For Sale:  Swiss .41 Vetterilin
postcontent:
Nice solid rifle. You can buy ammo for it and plink. Like a win 1873. 
Converted to center-fire, and be switched back.

The Vetterli rifles were a series of Swiss army service rifles in use from 1869 to circa 1890, when they were replaced with Schmidt-Rubin rifles. Modified Vetterli rifles were also used by the Italian Army.

The Swiss Vetterli rifles combined the American Winchester Model 1866's tubular magazine and a bolt system derived from the German Dreyse needle gun. They were also the first repeating rifle to feature a self-cocking action and a small caliber. Due to the Swiss Federal Council's early 1866 decision to equip the army with a breechloading repeating rifle, the Vetterli rifles were, at the time of their introduction, the most advanced military rifles in Europe.  The Vetterli was the replacement for Milbank-Amsler rifles, which were a metallic cartridge conversion from previous muzzle loading rifles.
